elements.content: Carbon dioxide capture and separation are of great importance for cutting greenhouse gas emissions. A series of Zr­(IV)-based MOF UiO-67-MIMS(x) (0 ≤ x ≤1) derived from mixed linkers 4,4′-biphenyl-dicarboxylate linker (BPDC) and its derivative bearing imidazolium sulfonate (BPDC-MIMS) at the 2-position were designed and synthesized. Their pore sizes and structures are well tuned by varying the x ratio of the two mixed linkers. Binary ionic liquid moieties (MIMS/salt) were furnished by subsequently incorporating the sodium salts within UiO-67-MIMS(x) , engendering a series of ionic liquid-decorated MOF composites, namely, UiO-67-ILs-anion (anion = Cl–, ClO4 –, BF4 –, PF6 –). The optimal pore size, the imidazolium sulfonate group with affinity sites to CO2, and various anions of ionic liquid moieties have a synergistic effect on the CO2 adsorption and separation. UiO-67-ILs-Cl ([Zr6O4(OH)4(BPDC-MIMS)1.5(BPDC)(4.5)]-NaCl) exhibited a high uptake of CO2 of 85.20 cm3/g (273 K and 1 atm), and its infinite dilution selectivity of CO2/N2 reached 36.56. All composites were characterized through powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), N2 adsorption isotherms, CO2-selective adsorption study, FT-IR spectroscopy, energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) spectroscopy, and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). The CO2 adsorption and selective roles of such MOF-based composites were systemically investigated by experimental and theoretical methods.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are porous materials assembled with organic linkers and metal ions/clusters via coordination bonds. In contrast to those carbon and zeolite molecular sieves, the tunable micropore sizes and structures within MOFs make them versatile porous materials for carbon dioxide adsorption with high performance. The pore sizes can be adjusted by simply changing the length of ligands, and the structures of pores/channels can be rationally decorated with various functional groups for CO2 adsorption. However, synthesizing a pore with precise size and subtle structure for efficient CO2 capture in a “fine-controlled” mode is still a major challenge for people. Generally, functional groups with adsorptive ability to CO2 are chosen and combined with MOF materials. For example, amino, imidazole, sulfone, and hydroxyl groups grafted on the MOF capture CO2 through electrostatic interaction, hydrogen bonding, ion-induced polarization forces, etc., exhibiting a synergistic effect on gas adsorption with high performance. Regarding the anion-functionalized MOF, a significant quadrupole moment of CO2 contacts with −NH2, the absorbate–surface interaction can induce high reaction equilibrium, and the porous structure plays an important role in enhancing the gas adsorption constant for high CO2 adsorption capacity.

elements.content: Ionic liquids (ILs) are widely applied in catalysis, electrochemical application, engineering fluids, chemical solvent, separation, analysis, and chromatography. Notably, ILs also exhibit strong ability to adsorb carbon dioxide through Lewis acid–base interaction, van der Waals interactions, and intermolecular contacts. We intend to fabricate ILs into MOF materials through de novo synthesis. Herein, introducing the zwitterionic group 1-(1-mthyl-3-imidazolio)­propane-3-sulfonate (MIMS) into MOF UiO-67 through a reticular synthesis method using mixed linkers H2BPDC (4,4′-biphenyl-dicarboxylate acid) and H2BPDC-MIMS (derivative with one MIMS group substituted on the 2-position of H2BPDC) in various ratios, a series of isostructural UiO-67-MIMS(x) (x = proportion of H2BPDC-MIMS linker) bearing different size pores were achieved as the x varied. Incorporating sodium salts (anion = Cl–, ClO4 –, BF4 –, PF6 –) into the pores of MOF, binary ionic liquid moieties consisting of MIMS zwitterions and metal salts are grafted on the UiO-67-MIMS(x) framework, namely, UiO-67-ILs-anion (). The control synthesis of the UiO-67-ILs-anion composites, the synergistic and combined effects of pore size, imidazolium and sulfonate groups, and various anions on the adsorption and selectivity for CO2 were investigated and discussed. UiO-67-ILs-Cl (containing a quarter BPDC-MIMS linker) exhibited a high uptake of CO2 of 85.20 cm3/g (273 K and 1 atm), and the infinite dilution selectivity of CO2/N2 reached 36.56. It provides a new feasible method for porous sorbent design with high selectivity for CO2.

The linker H2BPDC-MIMS (120 mg, 0.27 mmol) was then added to the clear solution and dissolved by ultrasonication for another 5 min. Then, the Teflon-lined autoclave was kept in an oven at 120 °C for 24 h under static conditions. After cooling down to room temperature, the precipitate was isolated by centrifugation. The resulting solids were washed and refluxed with methanol for 24 h to remove the unreacted linker and metal salts and then subjected to further drying at 120 °C under vacuum for 24 h. The desolvated/activated sample was kept inside a glove box for further use.

Structure and Physical Property

Zr(IV)-based UiO-67 (an MOF derived from the H2BPDC linker) is chosen in this study because it is thermally stable and tolerant toward high acidity. Also, its larger surface areas (3000 m2/g) and porous structure are important for gas adsorption. Its pores (tetrahedron with φ ~ 12 Å and octahedron with φ ~ 16 Å (V = 3082 Å3) interconnected/shared by triangular windows of φ ~ 8 Å) (Figure S3) are large enough for accommodating the MIMS groups (~6.70 Å across, van der Waals volume V vdW = 166.65 Å3). H2BPDC-MIMS is a derivative with one zwitterionic MIMS group substituted on the 2-position of 4,4'-biphenyl-dicarboxylate acid (H2BPDC) (). Identical powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of UiO-67-MIMS(x)  (x = 0.15, 0.20, 0.25, 0.30, 0.35, 0.50, 0.75, 1) indicate their same structure as that of the parent UiO-67 (a). So, the imidazolium sulfonate group (MIMS) and different BPDC-MIMS:BPDC ratios did not affect the framework structure of UiO-67-MIMS(x)  due to the same linker length of H2BPDC-MIMS as that of H2BPDC.

The gradually changed pore volumes and the sizes of the porous UiO-67-MIMS(x) are expected to combine the functional MIMS groups to efficiently effect the carbon dioxide adsorption. The sulfonate group and imidazolium of the zwitterionic MIMS groups can act as bonding sites for CO2 via dipolar interaction and Lewis acid–base effect, respectively, since the CO2 molecule has a large quadrupole moment and can induce polarization and enhance affinity to the zwitterions. However, as shown in a, the CO2 uptakes in UiO-67 and UiO-67-MIMS(x) did not gradually increase with increasing component (x values) of the BPDC-MIMS linker. This reason may be explained as follows: the functional MIMS groups on the BPDC-MIMS linkers can significantly promote the CO2 adsorption of UiO-67-MIMS(x) , while the increased MIMS balances this result due to the simultaneously reduced pore volume. So, a UiO-67-MIMS(x) with an optimal x value is expected to have the largest uptake capacity. UiO-67-MIMS(0.25) with x of 0.25 exhibits a maximum CO2 uptake of 66.28 cm3/g at 273 K and 1 atm, showing the highest CO2 adsorption performance (). This value is ∼1.8 times the adsorption capacity of the parent UiO-67 (36.92 cm3/g), although UiO-67 has a markedly larger pore size and surface area (). Obviously, the MIMS groups within the pores of UiO-67-MIMS(x) play a crucial role in improving the CO2 adsorption due to the dipolar contacts from −SO3 – and Lewis acid–base interactions from imidazolium groups. Notably, CO2 adsorption capacities linearly increased with the x increasing from 0.1 to 0.25, while they decreased as the x values were over 0.25 (0.25–0.75). For example, the value of UiO-67-MIMS(0.30) decreased to 46.56 cm3/g and further decreased to 20.47 cm3/g for UiO-67-MIMS(0.75) . These results indicate that the decreased pore size (due to the increased MIMS) plays the domain effect on the adsorption as x > 0.25. However, as x > 0.75, the CO2 adsorption of UiO-67-MIMS (x = 1) increased again and reached 43.05 cm3/g, being much larger than 20.47 cm3/g of UiO-67-MIMS(0.75) and even 36.92 cm3/g of UiO-67 (a). Obviously, the pore size is markedly decreased, while the affinity of the functional MIMS groups for CO2 uptake again becomes the dominant factor and enhances the adsorption in UiO-67-MIMS(x) as x > 0.75.

elements.content: To have a molecular-level vision of the reason for the significantly larger CO2 adsorption capacity of UiO-67-MIMS(0.25) compared to those of UiO-67 and UiO-67-MIMS, the free space simulation state of these MOFs was established through the “atom volumes and surfaces algorithms” method (). Structure and binding site analyses illustrated that strong CO2 adsorption sites can be formed as the atomic distance between two parallel groups is about 7.0 Å. Herein, due to the presence of the pendant MIMS on the linker BPDC-MIMS, the atom distances between MIMS and the benzene rings of the nearest linkers would lie within the 6.5–7.0 Å range in UiO-67-MIMS(0.25) , as shown in . So, the appropriate bonding sites for efficient CO2 adsorption are viable in UiO-67-MIMS(0.25) , and the adsorption capacity of which thus is enhanced with respect to that of UiO-67, although the latter has a larger pore volume and size (12–13 Å) (Figure S3). elements.content: To have insight into the effect of ionic liquids with various anions on the CO2-selective adsorption of such MOF-based materials, a series of UiO-67-ILs-anion bearing the ionic liquid (IL) moieties were synthesized using the predesigned imidazolium sulfonate groups on the MOF, namely, UiO-67-ILs-Cl, UiO-67-ILs-ClO4 , UiO-67-ILs-BF4 , and UiO-67-ILs-PF6 (, Figure S2, and Table S2). It is known that ILs can enhance CO2 adsorption as the CO2 with a quadrupole moment can contact with ILs via electronstatic and/or weak Lewis acid–base interactions. Imidazolium-sulfonate (MIMS)-based zwitterions are widely used to compose various binary ionic liquids. For example, Brønsted acid and alkali salt are generally used to blend with the MIMS zwitterions. Due to the Brønsted acid–base buffer and the charge delocalization effect, these composites exhibit the melting point or glass transition temperature lower than room temperature, leading to binary ionic liquids with multiple components. Herein, the predesigned zwitterionic MIMS groups of UiO-67-MIMS(x) can couple with pairs of anion and cation of the sodium salt to form the binary IL moieties within the pore region. Considering that high CO2 adsorption and a relatively large pore size were enough for the salt uptake, UiO-67-MIMS(0.25) was selected as a model to load the sodium salts with various anions (Cl–, ClO4 –, BF4 –, and PF6 –) through the immersing method (see ). Four UiO-67-ILs-anion composites contain the same BPDC-MIMS:salt molar ratio of 1:1 (Figure S2 and Table S2), furnishing the similar binary IL moieties of MIMS/salt with various anions.

elements.content: As illustrated in c, after the incorporation of NaCl into UiO-67-MIMS(0.25) , the adsorption of CO2 at 1 atm of UiO-67-ILs-Cl was significantly improved from 66.28 cm3/g to 85.20 cm3/g. However, the cases of the other three sodium salts (anion = BF4 –, ClO4 –, and PF6 –) resulted in decreased CO2 adsorption, although the BET areas and pore volumes of UiO-67-ILs-anion are slightly different (). The CO2 adsorption of UiO-67-ILs-Cl (85.20 cm3/g) is three times that of UiO-67-ILs-PF6 (27.20 cm3/g) and UiO-67-ILs-BF4 (28.59 cm3/g), being much larger than 52.55 cm3/g of UiO-67-ILs-ClO4 . Several reports indicated that BF4 –- or ClO4 –-related ILs generally exhibit better affinity to CO2 for high adsorption under the same conditions. Herein, the markedly improved CO2 adsorption of the Cl– case may be due to the synergistic effect of the binary IL, i.e., the pore size and the structure within UiO-67-ILs-Cl. In comparison, these polyatomic anions with larger van der Waals volumes may block the window and hinder CO2 from moving into the MOFs. Furthermore, to have more insight into the pore size effect on the adsorption of UiO-67-ILs-Cl, a series of UiO-67-ILs-Cl with variable x (0.15, 0.20, 0.25, 0.30, 0.35) were synthesized using UiO-67-MIMS(x) , and the CO2 adsorptions of which as a function of x (pore size) are shown in d. However, the adsorption reaches the highest value as x = 0.25, which can be explained by the combined enhancement of ILs and the larger pore structure. For example, as x rose from 0.15 to 0.25, the increasing adsorptions of UiO-67-ILs-Cl were observed, although the pore volume decreased with increasing x values (d). Meanwhile, as x > 0.25, the adsorption decreased, which may be ascribed to the markedly decreased pore volume and BET area of UiO-67-ILs-Cl.

Conclusions

In summary, we show the de novo synthetic approach to achieve an MOF-based material with a tunable pore size, structure, and functional ionic liquid moiety. The fine-tuned pore size and structure combine the functional ionic liquids to influence the adsorption and selectivity for CO2 of these MOF-based composites. The narrow pore of UiO-67-MIMS(0.25)  incorporated with equal molar NaCl, i.e., UiO-67-ILs-Cl, exhibited the highest selectivity for CO2. The markedly enhanced adsorption and selectivity for CO2 by synergistic use of the tuning effects of pore size, structure, and ionic liquid on an MOF-based composite were observed and elucidated. The covalent bonding of a binary ionic liquid on an MOF provides a new approach for new sorbent materials for CO2.

Carbon dioxide capture and separation are of great importance for cutting greenhouse gas emissions. A series of Zr­(IV)-based MOF UiO-67-MIMS(x) (0 ≤ x ≤1) derived from mixed linkers 4,4′-biphenyl-dicarboxylate linker (BPDC) and its derivative bearing imidazolium sulfonate (BPDC-MIMS) at the 2-position were designed and synthesized. Their pore sizes and structures are well tuned by varying the x ratio of the two mixed linkers. Binary ionic liquid moieties (MIMS/salt) were furnished by subsequently incorporating the sodium salts within UiO-67-MIMS(x) , engendering a series of ionic liquid-decorated MOF composites, namely, UiO-67-ILs-anion (anion = Cl–, ClO4 –, BF4 –, PF6 –). The optimal pore size, the imidazolium sulfonate group with affinity sites to CO2, and various anions of ionic liquid moieties have a synergistic effect on the CO2 adsorption and separation. UiO-67-ILs-Cl ([Zr6O4(OH)4(BPDC-MIMS)1.5(BPDC)(4.5)]-NaCl) exhibited a high uptake of CO2 of 85.20 cm3/g (273 K and 1 atm), and its infinite dilution selectivity of CO2/N2 reached 36.56. All composites were characterized through powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), N2 adsorption isotherms, CO2-selective adsorption study, FT-IR spectroscopy, energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) spectroscopy, and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). The CO2 adsorption and selective roles of such MOF-based composites were systemically investigated by experimental and theoretical methods.

Ionic liquids (ILs) are widely applied in catalysis, electrochemical application, engineering fluids, chemical solvent, separation, analysis, and chromatography. Notably, ILs also exhibit strong ability to adsorb carbon dioxide through Lewis acid–base interaction, van der Waals interactions, and intermolecular contacts. We intend to fabricate ILs into MOF materials through de novo synthesis. Herein, introducing the zwitterionic group 1-(1-mthyl-3-imidazolio)­propane-3-sulfonate (MIMS) into MOF UiO-67 through a reticular synthesis method using mixed linkers H2BPDC (4,4′-biphenyl-dicarboxylate acid) and H2BPDC-MIMS (derivative with one MIMS group substituted on the 2-position of H2BPDC) in various ratios, a series of isostructural UiO-67-MIMS(x) (x = proportion of H2BPDC-MIMS linker) bearing different size pores were achieved as the x varied. Incorporating sodium salts (anion = Cl–, ClO4 –, BF4 –, PF6 –) into the pores of MOF, binary ionic liquid moieties consisting of MIMS zwitterions and metal salts are grafted on the UiO-67-MIMS(x) framework, namely, UiO-67-ILs-anion (). The control synthesis of the UiO-67-ILs-anion composites, the synergistic and combined effects of pore size, imidazolium and sulfonate groups, and various anions on the adsorption and selectivity for CO2 were investigated and discussed. UiO-67-ILs-Cl (containing a quarter BPDC-MIMS linker) exhibited a high uptake of CO2 of 85.20 cm3/g (273 K and 1 atm), and the infinite dilution selectivity of CO2/N2 reached 36.56. It provides a new feasible method for porous sorbent design with high selectivity for CO2.

Results and DiscussionStructure and Physical Property

Zr­(IV)-based UiO-67 (an MOF derived from the H2BPDC linker) is chosen in this study because it is thermally stable and tolerant toward high acidity. Also, its larger surface areas (3000 m2/g) and porous structure are important for gas adsorption. Its pores (tetrahedron with φ ≈ 12 Å and octahedron with φ ≈ 16 Å (V = 3082 Å3) interconnected/shared by triangular windows of φ ≈ 8 Å) (Figure S3) are large enough for accommodating the MIMS groups (∼6.70 Å across, van der Waals volume V vdW = 166.65 Å3). H2BPDC-MIMS is a derivative with one zwitterionic MIMS group substituted on the 2-position of 4,4′-biphenyl-dicarboxylate acid (H2BPDC) (). Identical powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of UiO-67-MIMS(x) (x = 0.15, 0.20, 0.25, 0.30, 0.35, 0.50, 0.75, 1) indicate their same structure as that of the parent UiO-67 (a). So, the imidazolium sulfonate group (MIMS) and different BPDC-MIMS:BPDC ratios did not affect the framework structure of UiO-67-MIMS(x) due to the same linker length of H2BPDC-MIMS as that of H2BPDC.

The N2 adsorption property of UiO-67-MIMS(x) (x = 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 1) was selected and measured at 77 K. All samples display a typical type I adsorption isotherm, featuring characteristics of microporous materials. The pore sizes and BET areas of UiO-67-MIMS(x) vary with various x values (, Table S4, and Figure S6). As indicated in c,d, N2 absorptions decrease with increasing x value due to more BPDC-MIMS present in UiO-67-MIMS(x) . Meanwhile, the portion of 1 nm pores decreases, and a new pore of 6 Å appears as x > 0.5. These facts can be ascribed to the increased MIMS groups in the pores of MOF, which lead to the decreasing space for N2 absorption and the arising pore with smaller size. In comparison, UiO-67-MIMS with the neat ligand BPDC-MIMS shows a much smaller surface area and pore volume (324.67 m2 g–1 and 0.43 cm3/g, respectively) with respect to those of UiO-67-MIMS(x) (), as well as that of the reference UiO-67 (2407.42 m2 g–1 and 1.06 cm3/g, respectively). The pore volume and surface area of UiO-67-ILs-anion gradually decrease as the anions’ van der Waals volumes (V) increase (V Cl– < V ClO 4 − < V BF 4 − < V PF 6 − ) (). Due to the presence of sodium salts, these values of UiO-67-ILs-anion are slightly smaller than that of pristine UiO-67-MIMS(0.25) .

Pore Size Effect on CO<sub>2</sub> Adsorption

The gradually changed pore volumes and the sizes of the porous UiO-67-MIMS(x) are expected to combine the functional MIMS groups to efficiently effect the carbon dioxide adsorption. The sulfonate group and imidazolium of the zwitterionic MIMS groups can act as bonding sites for CO2 via dipolar interaction and Lewis acid–base effect, respectively, since the CO2 molecule has a large quadrupole moment and can induce polarization and enhance affinity to the zwitterions. However, as shown in a, the CO2 uptakes in UiO-67 and UiO-67-MIMS(x) did not gradually increase with increasing component (x values) of the BPDC-MIMS linker. This reason may be explained as follows: the functional MIMS groups on the BPDC-MIMS linkers can significantly promote the CO2 adsorption of UiO-67-MIMS(x) , while the increased MIMS balances this result due to the simultaneously reduced pore volume. So, a UiO-67-MIMS(x) with an optimal x value is expected to have the largest uptake capacity. UiO-67-MIMS(0.25) with x of 0.25 exhibits a maximum CO2 uptake of 66.28 cm3/g at 273 K and 1 atm, showing the highest CO2 adsorption performance (). This value is ∼1.8 times the adsorption capacity of the parent UiO-67 (36.92 cm3/g), although UiO-67 has a markedly larger pore size and surface area (). Obviously, the MIMS groups within the pores of UiO-67-MIMS(x) play a crucial role in improving the CO2 adsorption due to the dipolar contacts from −SO3 – and Lewis acid–base interactions from imidazolium groups. Notably, CO2 adsorption capacities linearly increased with the x increasing from 0.1 to 0.25, while they decreased as the x values were over 0.25 (0.25–0.75). For example, the value of UiO-67-MIMS(0.30) decreased to 46.56 cm3/g and further decreased to 20.47 cm3/g for UiO-67-MIMS(0.75) . These results indicate that the decreased pore size (due to the increased MIMS) plays the domain effect on the adsorption as x > 0.25. Carbon dioxide capture and separation are of great importance for cutting greenhouse gas emissions. A series of Zr(IV)-based MOF UiO-67-MIMS(x)  (0 ≤ x ≤1) derived from mixed linkers 4,4'-biphenyl-dicarboxylate linker (BPDC) and its derivative bearing imidazolium sulfonate (BPDC-MIMS) at the 2-position were designed and synthesized. Their pore sizes and structures are well tuned by varying the x ratio of the two mixed linkers. Binary ionic liquid moieties (MIMS/salt) were furnished by subsequently incorporating the sodium salts within UiO-67-MIMS(x) , engendering a series of ionic liquid-decorated MOF composites, namely, UiO-67-ILs-anion (anion = Cl-, ClO4 -, BF4 -, PF6 -). The optimal pore size, the imidazolium sulfonate group with affinity sites to CO2, and various anions of ionic liquid moieties have a synergistic effect on the CO2 adsorption and separation. UiO-67-ILs-Cl ([Zr6O4(OH)4(BPDC-MIMS)1.5(BPDC)(4.5)]-NaCl) exhibited a high uptake of CO2 of 85.20 cm3/g (273 K and 1 atm), and its infinite dilution selectivity of CO2/N2 reached 36.56. All composites were characterized through powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), N2 adsorption isotherms, CO2-selective adsorption study, FT-IR spectroscopy, energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) spectroscopy, and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). The CO2 adsorption and selective roles of such MOF-based composites were systemically investigated by experimental and theoretical methods.

Ionic liquids (ILs) are widely applied in catalysis, electrochemical application, engineering fluids, chemical solvent, separation, analysis, and chromatography. Notably, ILs also exhibit strong ability to adsorb carbon dioxide through Lewis acid-base interaction, van der Waals interactions, and intermolecular contacts. We intend to fabricate ILs into MOF materials through de novo synthesis. Herein, introducing the zwitterionic group 1-(1-mthyl-3-imidazolio)propane-3-sulfonate (MIMS) into MOF UiO-67  through a reticular synthesis method using mixed linkers H2BPDC (4,4'-biphenyl-dicarboxylate acid) and H2BPDC-MIMS (derivative with one MIMS group substituted on the 2-position of H2BPDC) in various ratios, a series of isostructural UiO-67-MIMS(x)  (x = proportion of H2BPDC-MIMS linker) bearing different size pores were achieved as the x varied. Incorporating sodium salts (anion = Cl-, ClO4 -, BF4 -, PF6 -) into the pores of MOF, binary ionic liquid moieties consisting of MIMS zwitterions and metal salts are grafted on the UiO-67-MIMS(x)  framework, namely, UiO-67-ILs-anion (). The control synthesis of the UiO-67-ILs-anion composites, the synergistic and combined effects of pore size, imidazolium and sulfonate groups, and various anions on the adsorption and selectivity for CO2 were investigated and discussed. UiO-67-ILs-Cl (containing a quarter BPDC-MIMS linker) exhibited a high uptake of CO2 of 85.20 cm3/g (273 K and 1 atm), and the infinite dilution selectivity of CO2/N2 reached 36.56. It provides a new feasible method for porous sorbent design with high selectivity for CO2.

Results and Discussion

Structure and Physical Property

Zr(IV)-based UiO-67 (an MOF derived from the H2BPDC linker) is chosen in this study because it is thermally stable and tolerant toward high acidity. Also, its larger surface areas (3000 m2/g) and porous structure are important for gas adsorption. Its pores (tetrahedron with φ ~ 12 Å and octahedron with φ ~ 16 Å (V = 3082 Å3) interconnected/shared by triangular windows of φ ~ 8 Å) (Figure S3) are large enough for accommodating the MIMS groups (~6.70 Å across, van der Waals volume V vdW = 166.65 Å3). H2BPDC-MIMS is a derivative with one zwitterionic MIMS group substituted on the 2-position of 4,4'-biphenyl-dicarboxylate acid (H2BPDC) (). Identical powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of UiO-67-MIMS(x)  (x = 0.15, 0.20, 0.25, 0.30, 0.35, 0.50, 0.75, 1) indicate their same structure as that of the parent UiO-67 (a). So, the imidazolium sulfonate group (MIMS) and different BPDC-MIMS:BPDC ratios did not affect the framework structure of UiO-67-MIMS(x)  due to the same linker length of H2BPDC-MIMS as that of H2BPDC. 

The N2 adsorption property of UiO-67-MIMS(x)  (x = 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 1) was selected and measured at 77 K. All samples display a typical type I adsorption isotherm, featuring characteristics of microporous materials. The pore sizes and BET areas of UiO-67-MIMS(x)  vary with various x values (, Table S4, and Figure S6). As indicated in c,d, N2 absorptions decrease with increasing x value due to more BPDC-MIMS present in UiO-67-MIMS(x) . Meanwhile, the portion of 1 nm pores decreases, and a new pore of 6 Å appears as x > 0.5. These facts can be ascribed to the increased MIMS groups in the pores of MOF, which lead to the decreasing space for N2 absorption and the arising pore with smaller size. In comparison, UiO-67-MIMS with the neat ligand BPDC-MIMS shows a much smaller surface area and pore volume (324.67 m2 g-1 and 0.43 cm3/g, respectively) with respect to those of UiO-67-MIMS(x)  (), as well as that of the reference UiO-67 (2407.42 m2 g-1 and 1.06 cm3/g, respectively). Due to the presence of sodium salts, these values of UiO-67-ILs-anion are slightly smaller than that of pristine UiO-67-MIMS(0.25) .

The gradually changed pore volumes and the sizes of the porous UiO-67-MIMS(x)  are expected to combine the functional MIMS groups to efficiently effect the carbon dioxide adsorption. Obviously, the pore size is markedly decreased, while the affinity of the functional MIMS groups for CO2 uptake again becomes the dominant factor and enhances the adsorption in UiO-67-MIMS(x)  as x > 0.75.

As illustrated in c, after the incorporation of NaCl into UiO-67-MIMS(0.25) , the adsorption of CO2 at 1 atm of UiO-67-ILs-Cl was significantly improved from 66.28 cm3/g to 85.20 cm3/g. However, the cases of the other three sodium salts (anion = BF4 –, ClO4 –, and PF6 –) resulted in decreased CO2 adsorption, although the BET areas and pore volumes of UiO-67-ILs-anion are slightly different (). The CO2 adsorption of UiO-67-ILs-Cl (85.20 cm3/g) is three times that of UiO-67-ILs-PF6 (27.20 cm3/g) and UiO-67-ILs-BF4 (28.59 cm3/g), being much larger than 52.55 cm3/g of UiO-67-ILs-ClO4 . Several reports indicated that BF4 –- or ClO4 –-related ILs generally exhibit better affinity to CO2 for high adsorption under the same conditions. Herein, the markedly improved CO2 adsorption of the Cl– case may be due to the synergistic effect of the binary IL, i.e., the pore size and the structure within UiO-67-ILs-Cl. In comparison, these polyatomic anions with larger van der Waals volumes may block the window and hinder CO2 from moving into the MOFs. Furthermore, to have more insight into the pore size effect on the adsorption of UiO-67-ILs-Cl, a series of UiO-67-ILs-Cl with variable x (0.15, 0.20, 0.25, 0.30, 0.35) were synthesized using UiO-67-MIMS(x) , and the CO2 adsorptions of which as a function of x (pore size) are shown in d. The larger the x value of UiO-67-MIMS(x) is, the smaller the pore size of UiO-67-ILs-Cl gets. However, the adsorption reaches the highest value as x = 0.25, which can be explained by the combined enhancement of ILs and the larger pore structure. For example, as x rose from 0.15 to 0.25, the increasing adsorptions of UiO-67-ILs-Cl were observed, although the pore volume decreased with increasing x values (d). Meanwhile, as x > 0.25, the adsorption decreased, which may be ascribed to the markedly decreased pore volume and BET area of UiO-67-ILs-Cl.

CO2 adsorption selectivity over N2 of UiO-67-ILs-Cl was investigated (). To establish the feasibility of these separations, selectivity calculation using the IAST method was performed (see ). To obtain excellent fitting curves, several isotherm models were tested to fit the experimental pure isotherms of CO2 and N2. The dual-site Langmuir model was found to be the best (R 2 > 0.9995) for UiO-67-ILs-Cl (). Based on adsorption data collected at 273 and 298 K, isosteric heat of CO2 adsorption values were calculated, as shown in a. The Q st value for UiO-67-ILs-Cl is 27.3–22.9 kJ/mol, being much higher than 15.9–15.8 kJ/mol for UiO-67. This fact further confirms the strong affinity of functional ILs to CO2 in UiO-67-ILs-Cl. Meanwhile, the value of Q st decreases with increasing CO2 adsorption, which is due to the adsorption sites gradually occupied by CO2 molecules during the process.

Compared to other representative MOFs reported, UiO-67-ILs-Cl (x = 0.25) also exhibits high adsorption capacity and separation ability for CO2, with the adsorption enthalpy reaching 27.3–22.9 kJ/mol, as shown in . Herein, the higher CO2 adsorption enthalpy (Q st) and CO2/N2 selectivity of UiO-67-ILs-Cl can also be explained by the synergistic and combined effects of the appropriate pore size and structure, functional groups (MIMS), and MIMS/NaCl ILs, which enhanced the gas adsorption and selectivity, although its BET surface area and pore volume are relatively small (1403.32 m2/g and 0.75 cm3/g, respectively) ().

Thermal Stability Study

Thermal stability at high temperature (150, 240, and 280 °C) of UiO-67-ILs-Cl was measured. The crystalline sample remained even at 280 °C for 24 h (Figure S1). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) profiles show that the decomposition temperature (T d) of UiO-67-ILs-Cl is comparable to that of UiO-67-MIMS(0.25) (>400 °C), being higher than that of UiO-67-MIMS (T d ∼ 380 °C). The zwitterions paired with the sodium salts decrease the pore volume, suppress the thermal vibration of the BPDC-MIMS linkers, and thus enhance the stability of UiO-67-ILs-Cl. Such high thermal stability is beneficial for the gas sorbent under harsh conditions such as high temperature.
